_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Covington Wastewater Treatment Facility (CWWTF) has chlorine on site that requires protection as defined under the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.  The City of Covington (the City) has implemented a PSM program to provide information to employees to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling and processing of highly hazardous materials.  The program emphasizes the application of management controls and standard operating procedures when addressing the risks associated with handling or working near highly hazardous chemicals.

The CWWTF treats and disposes of all sanitary waste discharged to the City Sewer System.  The facility utilizes four (4) 1-Ton cylinders (8,000 lbs.) of chlorine (a gas liquefied under pressure) in the wastewater treatment process.  The CWWTF handles 2.3 million gallons/day (MGD) and has a maximum load design of 3.6 MGD under National Pollutant Dishcarge Elimination System (NPDES) Permit Number TN0020982.

Worst Case:
Chemical and Amount Released:  2,000 lbs. of chlorine in 10 minutes inside the Chlorine Room.
Weather Conditions:  77 F with a 3.4 mph wind in Class F atmospheric stability.

This release would impact the urban area around the CWWTF within a 0.9 mile radius and affect 85 residences, an industrial park and two (2) churches.

Alternate Case:
Chemical and Amount Released:  2,000 lbs. of chlorine in 60 minutes inside the Chlorine Room.
Weather Conditions:  77 F with a 6.7 mph wind in Class D atmospheric stability.

This release would impact the urban area around the CWWTF within a 0.1 mile radius and affect two (2) small businesses; no residents would be affected.

The CWWTF is in compliance with OSHA PSM and emergency action plan regulations, as well as the EPCRA Section 302 rules.  The regularly scheduled maintenance program is key to maintaining the CWWTF in good operation.

There have been no accidental releases at the CWWTF during the last five (5) ye

ars.

The V-Notch Chlorinator is the equipment inspected daily.

Should there be a chlorine release, the Covington, Tennessee Fire Department (CFD) will respond.  The CFD has trained Hazardous Material (HAZMAT) technicians that can handle any accidental chlorine release.  The CFD provides emergency response training to CWWTF personnel.  Should the need for an evacuation occur, the Covington Police Department (CPD) will notify all households identified to be within a 0.9 mile radius.

Annual wastewater operator certification continuing education maintains and continually improves safety at the CWWTF.
